testTitle: Life in the UK Test - Tudors & Renaissance
testDescription: Comprehensive test covering the Tudor dynasty, Henry VIII, Elizabeth I, religious changes, exploration, and the English Renaissance period.

questions.stem: Who was the first Tudor monarch?
questions.explanation: Henry VII was the first Tudor monarch, who won the throne at the Battle of Bosworth in 1485, ending the Wars of the Roses.

questions.stem: The Wars of the Roses were fought between which houses?
questions.explanation: The Wars of the Roses (1455-1485) were fought between the Houses of Lancaster (red rose) and York (white rose).

questions.stem: How many wives did Henry VIII have?
questions.explanation: Henry VIII had six wives: Catherine of Aragon, Anne Boleyn, Jane Seymore, Anne of Cleves, Catherine Howard, and Catherine Parr.

questions.stem: Henry VIII broke with Rome to become head of the Church of England.
questions.explanation: True. Henry VIII broke with the Roman Catholic Church and declared himself Supreme Head of the Church of England in 1534.

questions.stem: Why did Henry VIII want to divorce Catherine of Aragon?

options.label: She had not given him a male heir

questions.explanation: Henry wanted to divorce Catherine because she had not given him a male heir, which he believed was necessary for the succession.

questions.stem: Which of Henry VIII's wives were executed?
questions.explanation: Anne Boleyn and Catherine Howard were both executed on charges of adultery and treason. Jane Seymore died in childbirth, Catherine Parr survived Henry.

questions.stem: Who was Mary I also known as?
questions.explanation: Mary I was known as 'Bloody Mary' because she burned around 300 Protestants at the stake during her attempts to restore Catholicism.

questions.stem: Elizabeth I was known as the 'Virgin Queen.'
questions.explanation: True. Elizabeth I was called the 'Virgin Queen' because she never married, claiming to be 'married to England.'

questions.stem: In which year was the Spanish Armada defeated?
questions.explanation: The Spanish Armada was defeated in 1588, marking a major victory for Elizabeth I's England over Philip II of Spain.

questions.stem: Who was the famous sea captain who helped defeat the Spanish Armada?
questions.explanation: Sir Francis Drake was one of the key English naval commanders who helped defeat the Spanish Armada, and was famous for 'singeing the King of Spain's beard.'

questions.stem: What were privateers?

options.label: Sailors licensed to attack enemy ships

questions.explanation: Privateers were private ship owners licensed by the government to attack and capture enemy merchant ships, essentially legal pirates.

questions.stem: The Elizabethan era was famous for which achievements?
questions.explanation: The Elizabethan era was renowned for literature (Shakespeare), exploration (Drake), and cultural achievements. Industrial development came much later.

questions.stem: Who wrote 'Romeo and Juliet'?
questions.explanation: William Shakespeare wrote 'Romeo and Juliet,' one of his most famous tragedies, during the Elizabethan period.

questions.stem: The Globe Theatre was associated with William Shakespeare.
questions.explanation: True. The Globe Theatre in London was where many of Shakespeare's plays were performed, and he was a shareholder in the theatre.

questions.stem: What was the Reformation?

options.label: A religious movement that broke from Rome

questions.explanation: The Reformation was a religious movement that challenged the authority of the Roman Catholic Church and led to the establishment of Protestant churches.

questions.stem: Which book did William Tyndale translate?
questions.explanation: William Tyndale translated the Bible into English, making it accessible to ordinary people for the first time.

questions.stem: The dissolution of the monasteries occurred during which reign?
questions.explanation: Henry VIII dissolved the monasteries between 1536-1541, seizing their wealth and lands for the Crown.

questions.stem: Sir Walter Raleigh was famous for introducing which crop to England?
questions.explanation: Sir Walter Raleigh is credited with introducing potatoes to England from the Americas, though he also brought tobacco.

questions.stem: The first English colony in America was called:
questions.explanation: Roanoke was the first attempted English colony in America (1585), though it failed. It was also known as the 'Lost Colony.'

questions.stem: The Tudor rose combined the symbols of Lancaster and York.
questions.explanation: True. The Tudor rose combined the red rose of Lancaster and the white rose of York, symbolizing the union of the two houses.

questions.stem: Which musical instrument was popular in Tudor times?
questions.explanation: The lute was the most popular musical instrument in Tudor times, used for both solo performance and accompanying songs.

questions.stem: Elizabeth I's court was known for its:
questions.explanation: Elizabeth I's court was famous for its magnificence, elaborate fashions, cultural achievements, and entertainment. It was anything but simple.

questions.stem: The Babington Plot was an attempt to:
questions.explanation: The Babington Plot (1586) was a plan to assassinate Elizabeth I and put Mary Queen of Scots on the throne.

questions.stem: Mary Queen of Scots was executed in 1587.
questions.explanation: True. Mary Queen of Scots was executed in 1587 after being implicated in plots against Elizabeth I.
